Gina runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells daily use products such as canned goods, shampoo, soap, toothpaste and biscuits to the local community. Gina has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Gina successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gina is requesting a new loan, her second from HSPFI, of 7000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Nou K., 33, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. K. is a housewife while her husband is employed at a factory, earning an income of 3 USD per day. One of her children is a factory worker, earning an income of 2 USD per day. K. has to spend 50 USD on food and 5 USD on other necessary expenses every month.

K. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to build a place for farmers to thresh their rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house.

loans.use: To build a place for farmers to thresh their rice

loans.name: Necty

texts.es:
Necty Hernández Z. es una señora de 62 años de edad y junto a su única nieta reside en el Barrio El Centro en el municipio de Guata, Olancho.

Necty tiene un negocio de servicio de fotocopiado y venta de útiles escolares e insumos para oficinas que opera bajo el nombre de “Papelería Luis Fernando”. Ella aprendió de este negocio por su hija, lamentablemente ésta falleció y Necty tuvo que hacerse cargo del negocio. Desde entonces su nieta y ella se turnan de 7:00 am a 7:00 pm para atender a los clientes. Su ventaja es que tiene una muy buena clientela porque la competencia es poca, ya que en el pueblo solo existen dos negocios con ese servicio. Entre los desafíos que enfrenta se encuentran la pérdida irreparable de su hija, la crítica situación económica que está pasando ya que no tiene la ayuda de nadie y su estado de salud porque es diabética y necesita un tratamiento médico, pero a pesar de esas dificultades agradece a Dios porque hasta el momento humildemente no le ha faltado nada.

Ella solicita el préstamo para la reparación de una impresora y comprar útiles escolares. Con el apoyo de este financiamiento considera que tendrá un mejor ingreso económico.

Sus sueños son que su negocio crezca para obtener mejores ganancias y así seguir apoyando a su nieta para que continúe estudiando hasta graduarse. Es su segundo ciclo en FAMA y con los prestamos que ha obtenido su negocio siempre ha estado bien surtido.
texts.en:
Necty Hernández Z. is 62 years old and lives with her only granddaughter in the El Centro neighborhood in the municipality of Guata, Olancho.

Necty has a photocopying service business and sells school and office supplies which she operates under the name "Papeleria Luis Fernando". She learned this business from her daughter, unfortunately she died and Necty had to take over the business. Since then she and her granddaughter take turns from 7:00 am to 7:00 pm attending to customers. Her advantage is that she has a very good clientele because competition is limited since there are only two businesses in town that provide this service. Among the challenges she faces are the irreparable loss of her daughter, the critical economic situation since she does not have help from anyone and her health because she is diabetic and needs medical treatment. Despite these difficulties she thanks God because humbly, until this time she has not lacked anything.

She is requesting this loan to repair a printer and to buy school supplies. With the help of this loan she thinks she will have a better income.

Her dreams are that her business will grow so that she can have greater profits and thus continue to support her granddaughter so that she can continue studying until she graduates. This is her second loan cycle with field partner FAMA and with the loans she has obtained her business has always been well stocked.

loans.use: Repair a printer and buy school supplies.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores C. is 42 years old, married and has four children. She is from the town of Surallah in South Cotabato province on the islands of Mindanao. Dolores farms and has been planting and harvesting rice crops for more than a few years now. She also has a piggery and grows pigs for breeding. Dolores aims to increase her rice yield and grow healthy pigs.

Dolores joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. Dolores successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP that will be used to purchase fertilizer and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pig feed

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana A. is 58 years old, married and has twelve school-aged children. She is from the village of Ricoro, a part of Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Juliana runs a store from which she sells a variety of fruits such as mangoes, apple, and pineapple to the local community. She has been in business for over thirty years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Juliana joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional fruits to buy and sell. Juliana is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Khat N., 46, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. N. is a farmer, earning an income of 1.5 USD per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of 5 USD per day. N. has to spend 110 USD on food and 25 USD on other necessary expenses every month.

N. is requesting a loan of 1000 USD for a motorbike to transport piglets to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house.

loans.use: For a motorbike to transport piglets to sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok K. S. is a professional teacher in the province of Kompong Chhnang and earns a formal salary. The couple is blessed with two children who are still enrolled in school. She has a life partner in her husband who works in the construction field.

Currently, she is concerned that one of her sons will marry soon but that she hasn’t enough in savings to help finance her son’s wedding. To solve this problem, Sok K. S. would like to request a loan to prepare for the wedding of her son.

loans.use: To prepare for the wedding of her son

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose M. is 37 years old, married and has six school-aged children. She is from the village of Bal-ason, a part of Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Mary Rose manufactures and sells brooms with her husband to local businesses and community members. Mary Rose has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2010 Mary Rose joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase the materials to manufacture additional brooms. Mary Rose is requesting a new loan, her third from HSPFI, of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional materials to increase broom production. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials to increase broom production

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong R., 59, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia – an area known for palm products. R. and her husband are farmers, earning $1.50 US each per day. One of her children is a motorbike seller, earning $10 per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

R. has to spend $55 US on food and $15 US on other necessary expenses every month. She is requesting a loan of $700 US to improve her child’s motorbike selling business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. R. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To improve her child's motorbike selling business

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita L. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. She is 56 years old. Purita is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Purita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling shampoo, soap, toothpaste, beverages, biscuits and junk food in the local community. Purita has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Purita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Purita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Purita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Purita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie B. is a 34-year-old woman from the village of Linconmonan, Gingoog City in the Philippines. Rosalie is married and has two school-age children. To earn a living, Rosalie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. She explains that her primary source of income is derived from buying and selling coconuts in her local community. She also makes and sells charcoal. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2010, Rosalie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. As a result, she is able to better engage in business activities and to improve her standard of living. Notably, Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. The prior loan was used to purchase additional coconuts to buy and then sell. Rosalie is now requesting a new loan, this time in the amount of 8,000 PHP ($200), which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital purposes. She plans to use the additional revenue generated on account of the requested loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and it reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Magielyn

texts.en:
Magielyn V. is a 39-year-old woman from the village of Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Magielyn is married and has three school-age children. To earn a living, Magielyn owns and operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector. More specifically, she operates a furniture-making business. Her primary source of business income is derived from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Magielyn has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2007, Magielyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to improve her standard of living. Recently, Magielyn successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. That prior loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Magielyn is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 22,000 PHP ($525), which will again be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product line. Notably, this loan would be the eighth loan taken out by Magielyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated on account of the requested loan to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand her product line by purchasing additional raw materials

loans.name: Phourng

texts.en:
Phourng I. is a 62-year-old married woman. She resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Phoumg is a housewife. Her three children are employed at factories, where they earn an income of approximately $3 per day to help cover the family's living expenses.

Every month, Phoumg has to spend approximately $25 on food and $8 on other necessary living expenses. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase rice in bulk, so that she can re-sell it when the price is right. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits generated as a result of the loan to repair her house.

loans.use: To pay for her family's living expenses by purchasing rice for re-sale purposes

loans.name: Roman

texts.en:
Roman is a married man, who earns a living by selling food at the food market in Drogobych town. Roman has been in this business for seven years. He explains that he enjoys selling food. His low prices, large assortment of goods, and excellent client service attract clients. Roman has many loyal customers that buy food from him all the time.

Roman is now seeking a loan in the amount of 7,500 UAH ($950) to increase the assortment of his inventory. He hopes to increase his sales and to make additional income as a result of the requested loan so that he can improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To increase sales by expanding his product line

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem N. is a 50-year-old married man, who resides with his wife and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. N. and his wife are farmers. Their three children are employed at factories, where they earn an income of approximately $4 per day to help cover the family's living expenses.

Kem explains that he has to spend $50 on food and $16 on other necessary living expenses every month. Kem is now requesting a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase a cow to raise for its offspring. In the future, he would like to use any additional profits generated as a result of the requested loan to repair his family's house.

loans.use: To improve his standard of living by purchasing a cow

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say K. is a 55-year-old pot seller in Kompong Chhnang Province. She sells her products in the village by using her motorcycle with her husband. She was blessed with seven children, all of whom are single. Two of her children are employed in different careers in Phnom Penh City. Her husband also helps her in the same business. This couple usually generates revenue of US$6 each day and they have been in their business for five years. She uses his cars horse as transportation and it takes a week to sell all her items. Say K. facing difficulties transporting her items because her horse cart is slow and small and it cannot contain in large amount of her products. Therefore, Say K. would like to borrow a loan to buy a trailer to attach to her existing motorcycle to transport her items.

loans.use: To buy a trailer to attach to her existing motorcycle to transport her items.  .

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz lives in Khanewal, which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, famous for its agricultural industry. She is married to M. Y. who belongs to an agricultural profession. He works in the fields to put three meals on the table for his family. He is a very hard worker growing wheat on his field to sell to customers. Shahnaz shares the financial burden for the family by doing labor works. She is the mother of seven children: five daughters and two sons. All of them are studying except the last three who are of not of school-going age yet.

Shahnaz has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy fertilizer and seed for his field to grow wheat for selling. He has been doing this business for the past 10 years and Shahnaz is hopeful that this investment will be profitable for her husband and, as a result, her family’s standard of living will get better. She is a new loan applicant and hopes it will be a profitable experience for her.  

In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (the Asasah passbook) in her hands is Shahnaz.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for an agricultural business

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en: Oksana is married with two children. She sells clothing at the central market in Drogobych town. Oksana has been in this business for 13 years. Oksana understands people and their needs. She has great communications skills that help her to be good in this business. She loves selling clothing and would like to develop her business further. Oksana is requesting 5,500 Grivnas to purchase seasonal inventories.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventories

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
A woman always wearing a smile, those characteristics simply describe Teresita S. of Oloc Laua-an, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Ernesto S. but unfortunately, they don’t have children. 

They earned their living through fishing. When Teresita joined ASHI a few months ago and received her loan of PHP 5,000, she started to put up a variety store in their barangay in order to earn more income. 

At the age of 60, she never stops dreaming of their future and she is more courageous right now when it comes to business because she already has experience in it. Above all, she knew that there are some people who are willing to give their trust to her and believe in her capacity. She wants to prove that she is not yet old when it comes to business and achieving their dreams.

Since they don’t have children, she focuses much of her attention on her business and on helping other people. For her second loan, she requested PHP 9,000. The loan will be used as additional capital in order to add the necessary items to her store. That way, her neighbors will not find difficulty in purchasing their needs.

Her greatest dream in life is to strengthen their relationship and if it is God's will, this variety store will turn into a mini-mart so that it will serve many people in the barangay.

loans.use: Variety Store

loans.name: Farhat's Group

texts.en:
Farhat is a resident of Khanewal, which is an agricultural city in Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house there and lives in it with her family. She is 28 years old and a very hard-working lady. She does labor work to financially support her family. Her husband, K. M., is a private entrepreneur and is involved in a dairy business. He has a buffalo at his home from which he gets milk and generates income for the family. 

Farhat is the mother of two daughters and two sons. The first three children are studying in a local school. It is Farhat’s greatest desire to provide her children a quality education so they become successful in life and make their parents proud. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s dairy business. With the loan, her husband will buy another buffalo and increase the milk production. She is hopeful that her husband’s income will increase by selling more milk.  

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Farhat”.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for her husband's dairy business

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad lives in Khanewal, which is a small city located in Punjab and is famous for its agriculture industry in Pakistan. She is 26 years old and lives there in a two-room brick house with her family. She moved here after her marriage a few years ago. 

She is a housewife and prefers to stay at home to do her household responsibilities. She is married to A. J. who works in the fields. He owns a small piece of land on which he grows wheat and other seasonal crops. He also operates a business selling fertilizer & seeds.
  
Irshad has given birth to three daughters and a son. None of them is of school-going age and Irshad wants to provide them a quality education once they become of school-going age. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy seeds & fertilizer to sell to his customers.  She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will prove a profitable experience for her family. 

Note: “In this photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Irshad”.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds for reselling

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma B. is a 62-year-old woman who has been raising three children and one grandchild all by herself after she separated from her husband. She and her children live in Jala-jala in the province of Rizal. Though their village is far from the market and main municipality, Norma never allows these circumstances to hinder her from earning money. She has been selling charcoal and purified drinking water in her neighborhood. She used to sell it in the village and nearby village to make sure that she would be bringing money for her family when she came back home.  Tiredness is not an excuse for her to stop what she has been doing.

Norma also started a hog-fattening business. The financial opportunities of hog fattening is one of the best ways to provide the basic needs of her family. The hogs will be raised for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale. Pigs will be sold either alive or slaughtered for its meat to be sold per kilo.

She has requested a loan of 22,000 PHP to buy more charcoal and gallons of purified drinking water and to support the maintenance of her hog fattening business for better output. She sees herself venturing into wholesaling charcoal and mineral water in the next five years. Norma is hoping that her envisioned businesses will help her to provide the financial needs of her family. By then, Norma positively thinks, their lives will be changed and she will have achieved her dreams.

Having her family, her own children, and ASHI, Norma is secure because she can have her own businesses, which can enable her to send her grandson to school until he completes college and to give her children a better life. They currently live in poverty.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and mineral water, and to support the maintenance of her hog fattening business.

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida lives in Khanewal, which is a small city located in the southern part of Punjab in Pakistan, known for its agricultural industry . She lives there with her family in a three-room brick house. She moved there after her marriage to B. A., 20 years ago. Her husband grows crops in the fields. He grows different kinds of crops like sugarcane, cotton and wheat, according to the season, and generates income for the family. His income allows him to manage the financial circle of his family.  

Shahida not only plays the responsibilities of a housewife, but also operates an animal sales business as well. She specifically deals with goats. She buys young goats, raises them up and sells them to customers in need. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. She has given birth to a son, who is an electrician by profession and also contributes to the family financially. Her family is very small, but they love to spend time with each other and share their happiness and sorrows with each other. 

Shahida has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her animal sales business. With the loan, she will buy young goats and improve her business. She is confident that this investment will bring positive change in her business and she will successfully sell more goats to her customers and makes her income double in size. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application.  

In the photo, the lady who holds a book (the Asasah passbook) in her hands is Shahida.

loans.use: To buy goats for reselling

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en: Natalya V. is divorced with a four-year-old son. She lives in a small apartment with her father and son.  She sells clothing at an open market in Ivano-Frankovsk town. Her monthly income is 5,000 Grivnas.  Natalya started this business three years ago. She used to work at the same market as a sales person, but then decided she could open her own business. Today Natalya has many repeat clients who buy from her. This business is the only source of income for Natalya. Natalya would like to increase the assortment of her inventories. She hopes to receive additional income and use it for her family's current needs.

loans.use: To increase the clothing assortment

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth V. is 47 years old and works as a fortuneteller in the Takeo province. She typically makes 1.50 USD every day and has four children: one is a mechanic, one is employed as a worker, and the other two are students. Her husband, pictured here, sells natural medicines, making 2 USD per day.

Muth V. is asking for a loan of 500 USD to purchase more mechanic’s tools for her son to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more mechanic's tools

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian L. is 33 years old, widowed and has four school-aged children. She is from the village of Tinabalan, a part of Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Vivian runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells biscuits, breads and snacks to the local community. Vivian has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Vivian joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Vivian successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou R. is 48 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Binakalan outside of Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Marilou runs a specialized store from which she buys and sells coconut or copra to the local community. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional coconuts to sell. Marilou is requesting a new loan, her third from HSPFI, of 11,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato C. is from the village of Minsapinit, Gingoog City. He is 44 years old, married, and has three adult children. To make a living, Renato owns and operates a bakery. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from baking and selling a variety of baked goods, especially a Filipino bread called pandesal or salt bread, in the local community. Renato has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Renato joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Renato has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional baking ingredients. Renato is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional baking ingredients and for working capital. This loan will be Renato's second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional baking ingredients and for working capital

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en: Nataliya is married and has one grown daughter. She sells women's clothing at the central market in Pavlorad, where she has a good location and carries quality inventory. Nataliya has been in this business for 6 years. She decided to start her own business to make additional income for her family after she lost her job because her company was downsizing. Her husband works at a coal mine. Their daughter is a third-year student at college. Nataliya and her husband help their daughter pay for tuition. Nataliya would like to borrow 15,000 Grivnas to purchase seasonal inventory. She has used business loans before and found them very helpful.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventory.

loans.name: Novederio

texts.en:
Novederio A. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. He is 28 years old. Novederio is single and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Novederio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Novederio has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Novederio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Novederio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used  to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Novederio is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Novederio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Nelio

texts.en:
Nelio P. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City (pictured is his wife, Mrs. P., because Nelio went to Manila for a job to obtain additional income for his family). He is 34 years old. Nelio is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Nelio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables, such as string beans and eggplant, to sell. Nelio has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP per month for these activities. Nelio and his wife help each other in their vegetable gardens. 

In 2010, Nelio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Nelio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Nelio is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nelio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Ibolya

texts.en:
Ibolya is a single mother who is raising her daughter herself. She works hard to ensure a decent livelihood for her small family. Ibolya started her business 10 years ago, when the used-clothing business was only getting started in Ukraine. Even today, there is still little competition at the market where she sells her inventory. This business is her family's only income.

Ibolya has used business loans before and finds them very helpful. She has been able to expand her business locations from one to three sites. Ibolya is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to increase the variety of her inventory. She would like to purchase more warm clothing and increase her sales.

loans.use: to increase inventory variety

loans.name: Damira Berdalieva's Group

texts.en:
Agriculture in Kyrgyzstan is a significant sector of the economy. Most of the farmland needs irrigation which is a challenge for farmers. A large part of land in Kyrgyzstan is used for crop cultivation, but even more of this mountainous country is used as pasture for livestock and animal husbandry. 

Damira B. is a 44-year-old farmer from Tokmok who is married with two sons. Her eldest son has a temporary income from his job and her younger son goes to school. The whole family relies on their land as a source of income. A basic part of their income is the sale of strawberries; they also cultivate land for other crops and raise livestock. Damira’s family took a risk to start raising livestock, but it has been a good decision with good results. They have purchased new carpets for their house, replaced old linoleum, and made household repairs. The family hopes to use this loan to purchase more livestock animals for breeding.  

Duishokul C. is 52 years old and also sells strawberries. Duishokul applied for this loan to purchase livestock to expand her business. She hopes that, after a while, she will be able to give her husband the car of his dreams and have a two-sided refrigerator for herself. 

Ainura M. is 37 years old and she and her husband sell strawberries. Ainura has already begun to enjoy the fruits of her labor. She hopes to use this loan to increase the number of cattle that she has as well as purchase new furniture for her bedroom.  

Aigul S. is 50 years old and is engaged in the strawberry business. She plans to use this loan to buy livestock. She is sure that she will be a success, because there was a time when her business was raising cattle.

 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
This is Lorna G., 40, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Arbi L. G. and mother to two young college kids and two high school students. By the grace of God, Lorna has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Lorna operates a direct selling business and manages a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling at piece rate prices. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 350 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 16,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Lorna dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Roseline Adhiambo

texts.en:
Roseline O. is 38 years old and married to Michael O.. They have seven children, all of whom are in school. 

Roseline has a small business that she has established of selling ready-made clothes. She has not been running it for long due to financial constraints; thus, the need for acquiring a loan to boost her business. She is applying for her first loan to enable her to get more stock and also to build up a shed where she can sell her clothes comfortably. 

Her dream is to one day be able to open a boutique and a hair salon.

loans.use: Buy materials for sale and clothes

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
This is Olivia C., 51, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Salvador C., a contractor, and is a mother to four young hard-working adults and five school-aged children. Two of her children are in college, one is in high school and two are in elementary school. By the grace of God, Olivia has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Olivia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling at the piece rate price.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Olivia dreams of being able to renovate her house soon with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Makun's Group

texts.en: The situation with social security in our country (Kyrgyzstan) is unfortunately very sad. Senior citizens have to worry about their financial condition, while as a matter of principle, they should have a quiet, carefree life. Such professions as a teacher, an engineer and a doctor were considered the most prestigious ones. But nowadays, the salary of teachers is so miserable that most of them have to start a business here or leave for another country to work at a worthy job. This story is about a teacher and a retiree, who happen to fight for a convenient life regardless of their degree and age. Makun M. is a 58-year-old retiree. She’s the leader of this group. She’s a resident of Tokmok and after the death of her husband, she was left alone with her son. Unfortunately the amount of her pension is too small for giving her son a quality education. So Makun had to go into business. Four years ago, she took a loan to get her poultry-keeping business started. She became experienced in taking care of animals and decided to go on to the next level. She hopes to succeed in getting this loan and spend it on broadening her poultry business and purchasing a calf and hay. If this brings her much income, she would like to get a cow also and start a dairy business. Zeinep Y., 24, is a young entrepreneur. She is busy with selling vegetables and fruits at the market. So after gaining this loan, she plans to increase the commodity circulation of her business. Rahima B., 50, has one 20-year-old daughter. Rahima is a dispatcher in the bus terminal of Tokmok. After a while, she decided that she could run a business at the same time. She bought livestock and gave it to her brother for breeding. Rahima applied to this loan for purchasing a calf and gaining as much profit from it as possible. Raliya Y., 47, is a teacher in high school. Raliya’s husband is a welder and they are the proud parents of five children. She lives by the bus terminal and started a business in the market nearby. This loan she plans to spend on increasing her commodity circulation and opening a second small shop. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Ma. Luna

texts.en:
Ma. Luna J. is a 49-year-old resident of Oloc, Laua-an, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Jorge J. and they are blessed with two children: Georgeline J., 21 years old, and George Junco Jr., 19 years old. Like other mothers, she has experienced difficulties and problems brought on by poverty but she has never given up. Instead, she encourages her children just to pursue their dreams. Her husband is very supportive which is why she is confident to face any challenges in their life. As the fruit of their perspiration and perseverance, her oldest daughter has already graduated from college and presently her youngest son is also in college.

Ma. Luna's first loan from ASHI was for 5, 000 Philippine pesos (PHP) and this was used to raise goats. Though she already has this project, she never stops thinking about the future of her family. For her second loan from ASHI she wants to start selling fish in order to earned additional income. She needs capital amounting to 8,000 PHP. Her greatest dream in life is for all of her children to finish college and earn degrees so that they will find stable jobs and stable income. She wants her children to never experience what their parents have experienced under the slavery of poverty. She is very thankful to ASHI and to all the people who have been part of opening the door of opportunities to her.

loans.use: For a fish vending business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther O. is 54-year-old widow with five children who are between the ages of 17 to 29 years. They live in the town of Migori.

Esther has a retail shop that she has been running for the past five years in town. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD  after being introduced by a friend of hers who really benefited from the loans she accessed from the group. She is in dire need of buying sugar, cooking oil, salt, etc. to add to her stock. She intends to use the profits made to invest back into the business. 

Her main desire is to buy building materials in the future and to be able to build rental houses in the next three years to come.

loans.use: Buy cooking fat,sugar,salt,cooking flour to add to her stock.

loans.name: Eleuteria

texts.en:
This is Eleuteria P., 51, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Gabriel P., an electrician, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are already working and settled down with their own families while the youngest will graduate from high school at the end of the school year. By the grace of God, Eleuteria has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Eleuteria as she herself was once a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Eleuteria operates a canteen and a small variety store and oversees the operations of a gown-for-rent business. In the Philippines, the whole working community and majority of families only eat home-cooked meals during the evening when all of the family members are at home to take part of the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal way of living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two people when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy greater quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Eleuteria dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings.

loans.name: Agrifina

texts.en:
This is Agrifina S., 42, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. Married and blessed with a high-school-aged child, Agrifina struggles and works hard for her family's future. She continually supports her child and is currently saving up for her child’s college education. Being a college undergraduate herself, she knows that there is nothing as important as an education for her child.

Agrifina operates a garlic and onion retailing business. Garlic and onion are the staples of Filipino cuisine. Every dish must contain either one or both of these. Agrifina purchases wholesale onions and garlic, cleans and peels them, repackages them into Php10 or Php5 bags and then sells them to the local markets and the immediate community. She is helped along by her family, a few neighbors and friends.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of garlic and onion to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Agrifina dreams to be able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of garlic and onion to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 46-year-old married man and has one child. He is from Lebanon. After quitting his last job at another company, he decided to start a business from his hobby of painting. He has prepared a painting atelier where he can work on his paintings. He really likes his job and he says that it’s a type of art in which he can express himself. He presents his paintings through some galleries.  Today, he is requesting to borrow $600 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase the needed painting tools and supplies. In the future, he hopes to organize a painting show and present his paintings to customers.

loans.use: to purchase painting tools and supplies needed

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda M., 45, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Mercelito M., a mechanic, and is the mother to a five young adults, all of whom are already working. By the grace of God, Erlinda has managed to support all her children’s educational needs. As of the present time she is working hard to be able to maintain her finances.

Erlinda operates an auto-repair shop. Her husband is the main mechanic while she handles finances, accounts, inventories and promotion. They offer repair, check-up and beautification of all types of cars and jeepneys - any type of vehicle that is referred to them. They also have a little refreshment stand in their auto-repair shop, where they sell beverages to the waiting customers and passing passenger vehicles.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy supplies like spare parts of cars, wirings, putty paint and others of the like. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Erlinda dreams or being able to have a good and comfortable life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy supplies like spare parts of cars, wirings, putty paint and others of the like

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok K., 50, is a professional scarf weaver in the Takeo province. She has been in this business since 2000 and is able to make about $2.50 of profit per day. In a day, she usually produces two to five scarves and each scarf costs around $2. Her husband is a worker, breaking and selling rocks. He earns $2 per day. 

This couple has four children: Two are in school and the others are employed. Sok K. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. This will reduce transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Yuriy

texts.en:
Yuriy is married. He sells fishing equipment at the local market in Vinogradovo city. Yuriy started this business four years ago. His kiosk is located right in the center of the market. There is almost no competition at this market, so Yuriy's business goes well. His income is about 4,000 Grivnas per month.

Yuriy is a hardworking person. He would like to develop his business further. He wants to purchase more inventory to attract more clients. Yuriy is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnas to cover the demand he has at the moment. Yuriy invests most of his income back into his business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Oah

texts.en:
Oah S., 36, is a professional silk scarf weaver in the Takeo province. She has been in this business since 2003 and is able to make about $2 of profit per day. Each day, she usually produces two to five scarves and each scarf costs around $2. 

Her husband is in security, making $2 per day. This couple has three children and all of them are in school. 

Oah S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase more silk.

loans.use: To purchase more silk

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita B., 45, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Fernando B., a technician, and is mother to a young working adult and a simple stay-at-home who manages the household while she attends to her business.

Teresita operates a photocopying business. There is more need now than before for services like these as customers’ demands increase. Her main patrons are students, who require her services for school requirements. She also has people who need her photocopier for documents, form replication and other similar needs. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in profit every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy a second hand Xerox machine, bond paper, toners, ink, and other supplies for her business. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy spare parts and repair fees for the photocopying machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Teresita dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy secong hand Xerox machine, bond paper, toners and ink, and other supplies for her business

loans.name: Maryam's Group

texts.en:
Maryam is a resident of Sumandri, which is a small city located in Punjab. This city is a big dealing center of rugs in Pakistan. All types of rugs (simple and designer) are available there for selling.

She owns a two-room brick house there and has been living in it with her family for over ten years. She is a housewife who stays at home and takes care of her family.

Her husband, S. G. Z., runs a private medical clinic in the community. He has studied a compounder (mixing drugs to fit the unique needs of a patient) course. He has a good knowledge of different common diseases and provides good quality health services to his patients who can’t afford the medicical expenses of big hospitals for treatment.

Maryam has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s medical clinic. With the loan, her husband will buy medicines, which will help him in better serving his patients.
  
Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds the book (an Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Maryam.

loans.use: To buy medicines for medical clinic

loans.name: Ung

texts.en:
Ung P., 31, sells chickens in the local market in Takeo province. She is married with two children who are still living at home, and her husband works in construction. She typically makes about US $6 each day and would like a loan to expand her business. She has many sources of income, one of which is weaving as she is pictured going here.

Since she spends a lot on transportation, she is asking for a loan of US $800 to purchase a motorbike to transport chickens to sell at the local market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Lita Bucol's Group

texts.en:
Lita B. is from the village of Sipaloc, Sibutad. She is 52 years old and is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if either is delinquent or defaults.

Lita is married and has six adult children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector growing crops to sell. Lita has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC which was used as additional working capital for the business. Lita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase a cow. This will be the fifth loan that Lita has taken out from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma D. C., aged 54, is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Harold D. C., a policeman, and is the mother of three children. By the grace of God, Irma has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Irma as she herself has been a college graduate (she took up a Bachelor of Science in Nursing) and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Irma maintains a direct selling business and a car-for-rent business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. The dealer’s cost prices are lower than those in the catalogue: the difference between the two is the profit that dealers earn as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, Irma is requesting a PHP 18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Irma dreams of being able to give all her children a good high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long L., 32, is a vegetable wholesaler in the local market of her Takeo province. She is married with one child, who is still living at home, and her husband is a policeman. She typically makes about US$5 each day and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$1200 to purchase vegetables in bulk and allocate them to small sellers in the village.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.en:
Wilfredo P. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. He is 55 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Wilfredo owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Wilfredo has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Wilfredo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Wilfredo is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the first loan that Wilfredo has taken out from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Yasmeen Muhammad Yaseen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is a resident of Sumandri which is a small city located in the Punjab. This city is a big trading centre for rugs in Pakistan. All types of rugs (simple and designer) are available there for selling. Yasmeen has a three room brick house and lives in it with her family. She is very responsible by nature and responsibly undertakes her responsibilities as a housewife.  

She is married to M. Y. who has a business selling crockery. He puts his crockery into a four-wheeled cart and goes out to sell in the morning and comes back home in the evening. He visits different streets of the city to sell crockery. 

Yasmeen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy crockery (jugs, glasses and cups) in bulk quantities to improve his selling. This loan investment will help him sell more variety and earn more from it. 

Note: In the photo, Yasmeen is the lady who is holding the book (called an Asasah Passbook) in her hands.

To make a living, Ireneo owns and operates a butcher shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from butchering and selling a variety of meats in the local community. Ireneo has been engaged in his business for over 28 years and earns approximately 12,800 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Ireneo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ireneo is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the second loan that Ireneo has taken out from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann S. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in the Takeo province. She makes and sells porridge and cakes from her home and is able to make about US$5 of profit a day. Her husband works in construction, earning US$3 per day. Since Vann S. sells porridge and cakes in the morning, she is asking for a loan of US$1200 to open a grocery store from which to sell after she has sold the porridge. She believes this business will bring more profit to help raise her family.

loans.use: To open a grocery store

loans.name: Nheb

texts.en: Nheb C., 36, is married and lives with her three children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works in construction making US$4 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have led to a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, including Nheb C.. She is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is 30 years old and is an aggressive businessman.  He runs a mobile phone shop in a very competitive environment but he still keeps his business profitable. He was previously selling clothes to earn a living. He has managed to stabilize his business which is three years old through Faulu Kenya. Joseph hopes that someday, he will transform his business into wholesale.  He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes to buy more phones.

loans.use: To buy more phones

loans.name: Khoun

texts.en: Khoun S., 39, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional tailor, making $1 a day and staying at home looking after her children. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver who rides a motorbike with a trailer attached. On average, he makes US$5 of profit every day. This couple has four children, three are in school and one is a garment factory worker. To earn more profit, she is asking for a loan of US$300 to raise pigs.

loans.use: To raise pigs

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is an industrious mother and is blessed with a very supportive partner, Edwin Quiatchon. She is 43 years old and a resident of Guinbanga-an, Laua-an, Antique, Philippines. She has four children; the oldest is 18 years old while the youngest is 11 years old. 

Due to poverty, her oldest child, John Webb, did not finish his elementary level, her second child is only in grade 6 while her third child as well as her youngest child are both in grade 3. Even though they are both industrious, they are still tied by poverty because they lack opportunities and resources. Her partner, Edwin, is a farmer while she is a laborer and housekeeper.

In 2009, ASHI came into Elizabeth's life. This was also the time when she started to open her eyes, broaden her mind and started dreaming of their future. After their training in ASHI, she received her first loan of PHP 5,000 which they invested in farming and it helped them to sustain their basic needs.

For her second loan from ASHI, she is borrowing PHP 8,500 and this amount will be utilized as starting capital for their buy-and-sell business dealing in muscovado sugar because their municipality (town) Laua-an is known as the muscovado capital of Antique. Muscovado is a type of unrefined brown sugar with a strong molasses flavor. Also known as "Barbados sugar" or "moist sugar", muscovado is very dark brown and slightly coarser and stickier than moist brown sugar. Muscovado takes its flavor and color from its source, sugar cane juice. It offers good resistance to high temperatures and has a reasonably long shelf life. It is commonly used in baking recipes and making whiskey. 

Elizabeth has a simple dream in life which is to send her children to school until college and she believes that it is not too late to start again. She wishes that her membership in ASHI will help her dreams come true.

loans.use: To use as starting capital for buying and selling muscovado sugar

Since Sim V. spends a lot on transportation, she is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike.

A very caring lady, Shafqat carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and takes care of her family. She is married to M. A. who is a carrier by trade. With the loan, her husband will buy a new donkey cart because the old cart has become rough and rotted in different parts which makes him unable to load items onto it and this is affecting his work. Shafqat is hopeful that her husband will successfully retain his customers by providing them good loading services.

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Mr. Ronald P. is from the Barangay of P4 Digson, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. He is 35 years old, single and has no dependents. To make a living, he is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store business. He’s been engaged in this kind of business for twenty years already. He is earning an approximate amount of $70 a month from this business activity. 

Just this year, Ronald joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronald, as a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, is requesting a loan amount of 15,000 PHP as his 1st loan,  which will be used to add to his capital for his business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments and possible business expansions.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

She sells clothes to financially support her family. She imports clothes from Faisalabad, which is very near to Samundri and famous for its textile industry, and sells to her local area clients. She has a good number of clients and receives regular orders every month.
 
She is married to M. R., who operates a dairy business. He has some dairy cows at his home and sells their milk to different milk shops in order to earn a good income.  

Surriya has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her clothing business. With the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk quantity that will lower her purchasing cost and enable her to attract more clients by introducing more of a variety of clothes to them. She is very confident that she will be able to make good changes to her current business situation with the help of this loan investment.

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean S. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Suol, Barangay Himaya, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: fishing and a fish-vending business. Her husband, Milo S., who is 39 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have five children who are 5 to 17 years old. 

Mary Jean joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 8 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mary Jean has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP helped her increase her monthly profit to about $355, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 9th cycle loan, she is borrowing 19,000 PHP, which she intends to use to do maintenance work on her fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Mary Jean S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase fishing gear and equipment

Ruby has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ruby joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruby is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ruby from HSPFI.
